item.title: Atlantic City Encouraged Voter Participation During Early Voting for 2025 Primary
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributor
item.description: Atlantic City successfully concluded its early voting period for the 2025 Primary Election, held from June 3rd to June 8th, allowing residents to cast their ballots ahead of time. The city emphasized accessibility and voter convenience throughout the process.
item.content:encoded:
The early voting period for the 2025 Primary Election in Atlantic County officially takes place from Tuesday, June 3rd through Sunday, June 8th, offering residents the opportunity to cast their votes ahead of Election Day.

Atlantic City government reminded residents that they did not have to vote in the town where they reside, making the early voting process more accessible and convenient for many. This flexibility allowed voters to choose from several polling locations across the county.

Voters took advantage of the early voting window to avoid potential long lines and last-minute issues on Primary Day. The initiative aimed to increase voter turnout and ensure that every voice could be heard well before the official election date.

Throughout the week, the designated early voting locations were open to all registered voters in Atlantic County, regardless of their municipality. This encouraged participation across communities and helped make the election process smoother and more efficient.

City officials and volunteers worked hard to make sure all voting locations were properly staffed and equipped to handle the volume of early voters. Voters appreciated the convenience and the organized process.

The City of Atlantic City continued its efforts to promote civic engagement by sharing information about the early voting dates and procedures through official channels and community outreach.

Clear signage and voter assistance were made available at polling locations, ensuring a seamless experience for first-time and returning voters alike. Accessibility was also a priority, with ADA-compliant facilities at all early voting sites.

This year’s early voting effort reflected the City’s commitment to maintaining a fair and transparent electoral process. Many residents expressed appreciation for the opportunity to vote at a time that best fit their schedules.

By promoting early voting, the City hoped to reduce Election Day congestion and make civic participation more inclusive and manageable.

The success of the early voting period set a strong foundation for future elections, reinforcing the importance of community involvement and voter preparedness.

item.title: Atlantic City Seniors Explore Nature During 2nd Annual Black Birders Event at Forsythe Refuge
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services hosted its 2nd Annual Black Birders Event at the Edwin B. Forsythe Wildlife Refuge, offering seniors a day of learning, exploration, and connection with nature. The event featured a scenic wetland drive, a guided forest hike, and a shared lunch.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Senior Services recently held its 2nd Annual Black Birders Event at the Edwin B. Forsythe Wildlife Refuge, offering local seniors an unforgettable day immersed in the beauty and education of the natural world.

The event was designed to highlight the importance of inclusivity in outdoor spaces while celebrating Black Birders Week, a national movement that promotes diversity in birding and environmental awareness.

Seniors participated in a range of outdoor activities beginning with a scenic drive tour through the Wetlands, where they observed local wildlife and learned about the ecology of the refuge. The ride provided a relaxing and informative introduction to the day’s exploration.

Following the drive, participants enjoyed a delicious lunch that gave everyone a chance to socialize and reflect on their surroundings. The sense of community and appreciation for nature was present throughout the event.

After lunch, seniors embarked on a guided hike through the forest trails of the reserve. With the help of expert guides, they explored native plants, birds, and ecosystems that are unique to the Forsythe area.

The hike not only allowed for physical activity but also sparked conversations about environmental stewardship and the importance of preserving local habitats for future generations.

The Friends of Forsythe NWR played a critical role in making this day possible, offering support, guidance, and resources that made the event both educational and enjoyable.

‍

Atlantic City Senior Services emphasized how fortunate the city is to have such rich natural resources nearby. They expressed gratitude for the opportunity to expose seniors to these experiences and encourage lifelong learning.

The event reinforced the idea that it's never too late to learn something new, enjoy nature, and be part of a meaningful cause. It also highlighted the ongoing commitment of the city to support inclusive programming for all its residents.

This annual tradition continues to grow in impact and popularity, and Atlantic City Senior Services looks forward to expanding the event even further in the years to come.

‍

item.title: Atlantic City Graduates 27 Aspiring Entrepreneurs through Small Business Academy
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The City of Atlantic City proudly celebrated the graduation of 27 residents from its Small Business Academy, an eight-week intensive program designed to guide aspiring entrepreneurs. The latest cohort concluded with a pitch competition, awarding a $15,000 grant to local caterer Tabriah Taylor.
item.content:encoded:
Twenty-seven Atlantic City residents celebrated a major milestone this week, completing the City’s Small Business Academy, a free, eight-week training program that prepares residents to start and grow successful businesses.

The program, a partnership between the City of Atlantic City and the African American Chamber of Commerce of New Jersey (AACCNJ), featured expert-led workshops covering essential business topics such as licensing and registration, business planning, goal setting, marketing, and more. The course concluded with a pitch competition where participants presented their business ideas to local professionals for feedback and scoring.

‍

Tabriah Taylor was named the top presenter for her plan to expand her catering business and received a $15,000 grant from the Inlet Community Development Corporation (CDC). Lonniyell Sykes and Paidra Lucas were awarded second and third place, respectively.

Established in 2021 under the leadership of Mayor Marty Small Sr., the Small Business Academy is part of a larger effort to promote inclusive economic development and equip residents with practical tools for long-term success. The Mayor has prioritized investing in residents as a way to grow the local economy from within, focusing on initiatives that build self-sufficiency, innovation, and opportunity.

The City’s Economic Development Department, led by Bruce Weekes and Pam Fields, coordinated this latest cohort alongside Carmen Gates, AACCNJ Vice President of Community Development and External Affairs. Their efforts reflect the City’s ongoing work to cultivate entrepreneurship at the neighborhood level.

This graduation comes as part of a broader strategy to support small businesses across Atlantic City. Earlier this month, the City launched the Keep it Local campaign and declared May Small Business Month, encouraging residents and visitors to support locally owned businesses and showcasing the vital role these businesses play in the city’s growth and culture.

Together, these efforts signal a clear focus: Atlantic City is committed to being a place where people can thrive, work, and invest. The Small Business Academy is not only helping individuals pursue their dreams, it’s helping to build a stronger, more resilient Atlantic City.

item.title: Atlantic City Commemorated Memorial Day with a Special Ceremony at All Wars Memorial Building
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City marked Memorial Day with a heartfelt observance at the All Wars Memorial Building, commemorating its 100-year anniversary and honoring the fallen with dignity and gratitude. The community gathered in solemn remembrance of those who served and sacrificed.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City held its annual Memorial Day Observance with a moving tribute to the courageous men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice in service to the United States. The community came together in solemn remembrance, honoring the legacy of those who laid down their lives to protect the nation's freedoms.

This year's observance took on an even more poignant tone as it coincided with the 100-year anniversary of the All Wars Memorial Building. The event was held at this historic site, which has long stood as a testament to the valor and dedication of American service members across generations.

Local officials, veterans, community leaders, and residents gathered for the ceremony, reflecting on the significance of Memorial Day and the continued importance of preserving its meaning. The Memorial Day Observance featured heartfelt speeches, the laying of wreaths, and a moment of silence in memory of the fallen.

Veterans and family members of those who served shared personal stories, adding a powerful emotional depth to the occasion. Their accounts reminded attendees of the real human cost of war and the enduring bravery of those who answered the call of duty.

The All Wars Memorial Building served not only as the backdrop but as a symbol of resilience and remembrance. Its centennial celebration marked a century of honoring service and sacrifice within the Atlantic City community.

Musical tributes, including performances of the national anthem and other patriotic songs, further enhanced the reflective atmosphere. Attendees stood united in respect, many wearing symbolic red, white, and blue to show solidarity.

Children and students were also present, some participating in the event, demonstrating the importance of educating the next generation about the value of remembrance and national service.

Mayor Marty Small Sr., along with other city officials, emphasized the city’s commitment to honoring its veterans and the ongoing efforts to maintain Atlantic City as a place of historical significance and civic pride.

The Memorial Day Observance served as a powerful reminder that freedom comes at a cost—and that cost is borne by brave individuals and their families. Atlantic City’s tribute was both heartfelt and dignified, capturing the spirit of unity and respect.

As the event concluded, attendees were invited to reflect at the memorial, leaving flowers and flags in tribute. The ceremony was a fitting homage to those who gave all, and a reaffirmation of the community’s enduring gratitude.

item.title: Starting a Business? Here’s Why You Should Do It in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: With new resources, citywide support, and a culture of entrepreneurship, Atlantic City is primed for small business success.
item.content:encoded:
For over 25 years, Joe Molineaux has been at the intersection of community and commerce—guiding municipalities and individuals through the challenges and opportunities of launching and growing businesses. Now, as a business development consultant for the City of Atlantic City, Molineaux says he’s never seen conditions more favorable for entrepreneurs than what exists in the city today.

“There’s never been a better time, based on the resources available, the commitment of city leadership, the real estate options, and the current business needs—for someone to start a business in Atlantic City,” said Molineaux.

That optimism isn’t just rhetoric—it’s backed by a groundswell of programs and infrastructure designed to support local entrepreneurs at every stage of their journey.

A City Committed to Nurturing New Business

Molineaux recently partnered with the City’s Department of Planning & Development to lead a free “Navigating the Process” seminar at City Hall. The goal? To demystify the first steps of starting a business and connect aspiring entrepreneurs with the tools and people they need to succeed.

The seminar offered real-world insights into:

  • Why now is the perfect time to launch a business in Atlantic City
  • Common pitfalls and misconceptions about entrepreneurship
  • Steps for registering and licensing a new business
  • How to create a business plan that works
  • Funding sources and local supports available

According to Molineaux, what makes Atlantic City unique isn’t just the affordability of commercial real estate or the increasing foot traffic from new development—it’s the ecosystem of support.

“From the City’s direct investment in entrepreneurship to the Community Development Corporations (CDCs) located in every ward, Atlantic City is leading the way in creating a nurturing environment for business owners,” he said. “There’s a genuine effort here to move residents forward—not just through business ownership, but through education, mentorship, and support for day-to-day living.”

A City on the Move

Molineaux's message echoes a broader truth felt across Atlantic City: this is a city on the rise, and entrepreneurship is one of its most powerful tools for equitable growth.

Through initiatives like the Small Business Academy, the “How to Do Business with Atlantic City” seminars, and the newly launched Keep It Local campaign, Mayor Marty Small Sr. and the Planning & Development team are making it clear: Atlantic City is not only open for business—it’s investing in it.

This spring, the City also declared May as “Small Business Month”, highlighting the critical role small businesses play in local identity, economic development, and generational opportunity.

Advice for Future Founders

For those considering a business of their own, Molineaux offers this advice:
“Do something every day that moves your dream forward. Research, ask questions, find mentors. Don’t go it alone—and don’t wait for perfect timing. The time is now.”

Additional “Navigating the Process” workshops are already being planned in Atlantic City for the months ahead. Residents interested in launching a business are encouraged to connect with their local CDCs or the City’s Department of Planning & Development for updates and support.

item.title: Mayor Small and Atlantic City Honored Fallen Heroes at Memorial Day Ceremony
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Mayor Marty Small Sr. and the City of Atlantic City honored our fallen heroes during a solemn and heartfelt Memorial Day Ceremony at the Saracini-O'Neill 9/11 Memorial. The event served as a powerful tribute to those who made the ultimate sacrifice in service to the nation.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City, led by Mayor Marty Small Sr., commemorated Memorial Day with a touching ceremony held at the Saracini-O'Neill 9/11 Memorial. The gathering was a moving tribute to the brave men and women who have given their lives in defense of the country.

Set against the backdrop of the city’s 9/11 memorial, the ceremony brought together city officials, veterans, families, and community members to reflect on the meaning of sacrifice, service, and remembrance.

Mayor Small and other city leaders delivered remarks that emphasized the importance of remembering those who served and honoring their legacy not just on Memorial Day, but every day.

The event marked the beginning of the Memorial Day weekend, reminding residents and visitors alike of the true significance behind the holiday.

The Saracini-O'Neill 9/11 Memorial, named in honor of local heroes, provided a poignant and powerful setting for the ceremony. Attendees were encouraged to pause, reflect, and pay their respects to those who gave their lives for freedom.

The City also announced an additional Memorial Day Observance, which was scheduled for the following day at the All Wars Memorial Building located at 1510 Adriatic Avenue. This observance aimed to further honor the memory of all fallen service members across generations and conflicts.

These ceremonies are part of Atlantic City’s ongoing commitment to recognize and uplift the stories of veterans and fallen soldiers, ensuring their bravery and service are never forgotten.

Residents and visitors who attended the event shared a sense of unity, patriotism, and deep appreciation for those who have defended our nation.

The City of Atlantic City extended its gratitude to all who participated in the ceremonies and encouraged continued support for military families and veteran communities throughout the year.

item.title: Atlantic City Residents Experienced Art, Culture, and Peace at BAPS Shri Swaminarayan
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services team and local residents visited the BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir in Robbinsville for a peaceful and enriching cultural experience. The trip offered an opportunity to reflect on art, architecture, and cultural understanding.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services recently visited the BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir – Akshardham in Robbinsville, New Jersey. Known as the Cultural Jewel of India, the mandir offered residents a unique and unforgettable journey into traditional Indian art, architecture, and spirituality.

The visit highlighted the stunning craftsmanship of the mandir, which features intricate hand-carved stonework and traditional design elements. Participants were guided through the site, where they learned about the construction process and the cultural and spiritual significance behind every detail.

The group had the opportunity to reflect in the mandir’s serene and peaceful environment, making the visit not only educational but also deeply calming and introspective.

Beyond its architectural beauty, the mandir serves as a vibrant community hub, offering programs and initiatives that promote service, unity, and cultural understanding. These values align closely with the mission of Atlantic City’s Multicultural Services to foster inclusion and respect across diverse communities.

The outing provided a meaningful opportunity for residents to connect with traditions outside their own and to deepen their appreciation for the richness of global cultures.

It also reinforced the importance of cultural exploration as a path toward greater empathy, awareness, and peaceful coexistence in our increasingly interconnected world.

Participants shared their reflections and expressed gratitude for the chance to experience such a powerful example of living tradition and artistry.

The trip served as a reminder of the beauty and value found in engaging with different cultures, and how such experiences can broaden perspectives and strengthen community bonds.

The City of Atlantic City thanked everyone who joined the outing and looks forward to organizing more cultural visits that inspire learning, connection, and mutual respect.

item.title: Atlantic City's 2025 Summer Season Begins with Traditional Sea Unlocking Ceremony
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Mayor Marty Small Sr. kicked off Memorial Day Weekend and the 2025 summer season by ceremonially unlocking the sea in front of Resorts Casino Hotel. The event marked the beginning of what is expected to be one of the city’s biggest summers in years.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City officially opened its 2025 summer season with the annual “Opening of the Sea” ceremony, led by Mayor Marty Small Sr. Held outside Resorts Casino Hotel, the event marked the ceremonial start of Memorial Day Weekend and the summer festivities.

Mayor Small continued the city’s tradition by unlocking the sea, a symbolic gesture that signals the start of beach and boardwalk season. In his remarks to the crowd, he emphasized the significance of this summer for Atlantic City.

“This summer is going to be one of the biggest summers we’ve had in a very, very, very long time,” Mayor Small told attendees. “And it’s because of the spirit of cooperation between my administration and the casino industry. We are committed now more than ever to make Atlantic City the best place it can be.”

The mayor’s optimism reflected the strong partnership between city leadership and local stakeholders, who have worked together to ensure a safe, exciting, and prosperous season for residents and visitors alike.

Joining Mayor Small at the event were several key city officials and community leaders. These included Atlantic City Police Department Chief James Sarkos, Atlantic City Fire Department Chief and Office of Emergency Management Coordinator Scott Evans, Atlantic City Beach Patrol Chief Steve Downey, Public Safety Director Sean Riggin, and Resorts Casino Hotel President and CEO Mark Giannantonio.

Their presence underscored the city’s focus on public safety, emergency preparedness, and community engagement as critical components of the summer season.

The “Opening of the Sea” ceremony has long been a cherished tradition in Atlantic City, celebrating the city’s connection to the ocean and its role as a top summer destination on the East Coast.

‍

With the season officially underway, city departments and community partners prepared to welcome thousands of visitors to Atlantic City’s beaches, boardwalk, and attractions.

The kickoff event not only highlighted the city's readiness for summer but also showcased its unity and shared vision for continued growth and success.

As the 2025 summer season began, the energy and excitement of the opening ceremony served as a powerful reminder of Atlantic City's resilience, hospitality, and commitment to being a world-class destination.

item.title: Atlantic City Honors Local Businesses and IT Department for Innovation, Impact, and Community Excellence
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Celebrating the people and organizations helping Atlantic City grow stronger, smarter, and more connected.
item.content:encoded:
At a recent City Council meeting, the City of Atlantic City recognized a group of exceptional local businesses and dedicated city staff whose efforts are helping shape a more vibrant, efficient, and forward-thinking Atlantic City. From restaurant owners to IT technicians, these honorees represent the best of what it means to live, work, and invest in the city.

Celebrating Small Business Month: Local Legends and Community Cornerstones

In honor of Small Business Month, the City’s Economic Development team—part of the Planning & Development Department—formed an internal committee to highlight small businesses that have made an undeniable impact on the local economy and community life.

The inaugural group of honorees included a diverse and dynamic lineup of beloved establishments:

  • Dock’s Oyster House – Business Excellence Award
  • Gilchrist Restaurant – Resiliency Award
  • Barbera Seafood Market – Community Spirit Award
  • The Irish Pub Atlantic City – Community Spirit Award
  • Kelsey’s Atlantic City – Growth & Economic Development Award
  • Tony Boloney’s / Mad Mutz – Innovation Award
  • Swapz AC – Emerging Pioneer Award
  • Vagabond Kitchen & Tap House – Community Impact Award
  • Miss Audrey’s Thrift Shop – Legacy Award

Recognizing neighborhood-specific contributions, local Community Development Corporations (CDCs) also nominated outstanding small businesses in their respective wards:

  • North Beach Mini Golf (Inlet CDC)
  • Center City Deli (Midtown CDC)
  • Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria (Ducktown CDC)

These businesses are more than storefronts—they are economic drivers, cultural landmarks, and places where the community gathers, celebrates, and supports one another. Their recognition reflects the city’s larger mission to make Atlantic City a place where entrepreneurship thrives and local pride runs deep.

Spotlight on Innovation: IT Department Delivers Big Wins Behind the Scenes

While local business owners power Atlantic City’s street-level economy, the City Council also took time to celebrate the often-unseen efforts of its own team, specifically, the Information Technology (IT) Department.

Led by Director Patrick Quinlan and supported by team members Tony Dabney and Kyshawn Wyman, the department was honored for recent accomplishments that have had a direct financial and operational impact on the city.

Among their standout achievements:

  • Saving more than $250,000 at Pop Lloyd Stadium and over $100,000 at the Atlantic City Aquarium by installing advanced surveillance systems in-house rather than outsourcing the work.
  • Playing a critical role in preventing a major cybersecurity attack, demonstrating not only technical expertise but also a proactive commitment to safeguarding city operations and resident data.

These efforts embody the kind of innovation, accountability, and behind-the-scenes excellence that keeps Atlantic City running efficiently and safely. It’s also a reminder that every dollar saved is a dollar that can be reinvested into community services, infrastructure, and future opportunities.

‍

‍

‍

A Culture of Recognition, a City on the Rise

Together, the honored businesses and IT professionals represent the diverse strengths within Atlantic City—vision, resilience, creativity, and dedication. Whether it’s through customer service or server security, each honoree is playing a role in the city’s ongoing transformation.

By taking the time to publicly acknowledge their contributions, the City of Atlantic City reinforces a culture of appreciation, excellence, and shared progress.

This is what it looks like when a city prioritizes its people—not just through programs, but through recognition, investment, and action.

item.title: A New Era of Leadership in the Atlantic City Fire Department
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Fire Department proudly celebrated the promotion of its newest battalion chiefs and captains, marking a significant milestone in the city’s public safety leadership.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City took great pride in honoring its dedicated public servants during a heartfelt promotion ceremony held at City Hall Council Chambers on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. The event marked a significant moment for the Atlantic City Fire Department, as a new generation of leaders stepped into their roles with commitment and honor.

Four exemplary firefighters were officially promoted to the esteemed rank of battalion chief. These individuals—Timothy Kuras, Ariel Beltran, Kyle Pollock, and Kenton Brookings—have demonstrated exceptional leadership, courage, and service throughout their careers, earning the trust and respect of both their peers and the community.

In addition to the battalion chiefs, the department proudly promoted six firefighters to the rank of captain. Those recognized were Jamieson Allen, Joseph Caprio, Joseph Welsh, Jack Rush, Thomas Higbee, and William Hamilton, Jr. Each of them has shown unwavering dedication and a deep commitment to the safety and well-being of Atlantic City’s residents.

The event was more than just a ceremony; it was a celebration of service, legacy, and the future of the department. Fire Chief Scott K. Evans opened the proceedings with remarks that acknowledged the hard work and perseverance of the honorees and underscored the importance of leadership in emergency services.

Director Sean Riggin shared a message of encouragement and pride, reflecting on the growth of the department and the promise these leaders bring to the city. DCA Commissioner Jacquelyn A. Suarez also took to the podium, recognizing the regional impact of the department’s leadership and the strength of public service in New Jersey.

A highlight of the ceremony was the address by Mayor Marty Small, Sr., who administered the oath of office to each newly promoted member. His words emphasized the city’s gratitude and the vital role these individuals play in keeping Atlantic City safe.

As each honoree stood before colleagues, friends, and family, the ceremony served as a powerful reminder of the responsibility that comes with leadership in public safety. The event was filled with emotion, pride, and unity—hallmarks of the Atlantic City Fire Department's tradition.

The promotion ceremony was not just about titles, but about a shared mission to protect and serve. It reflected a collective commitment to excellence, resilience, and honor.

With these promotions, the Atlantic City Fire Department steps forward into a new chapter—one led by seasoned, skilled, and passionate professionals dedicated to the community’s well-being.

‍

Credit: Ed Lea / City of Atlantic City

item.title: Honoring Those Who Served: Atlantic City Supports Veterans at South Jersey Regional Stand Down
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City joined community leaders, volunteers, and organizations at the South Jersey Regional Stand Down, offering care and critical services to homeless and at-risk veterans. The event, held at the All Wars Memorial Building, served as a powerful reminder of our duty to those who served.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City recently stood in strong support of its veteran community during the annual South Jersey Regional Stand Down at the historic All Wars Memorial Building. This impactful event brought together local leaders, volunteers, and agencies in a united effort to serve those who once served us.

Mayor Marty Small Sr. and city officials were present to engage with veterans and reinforce the city’s ongoing commitment to their well-being. The event provided a wide range of services to homeless and at-risk veterans, many of whom face daily struggles navigating access to care, benefits, and basic resources.

Throughout the day, veterans received hot meals, clothing, and access to medical care, mental health services, and benefits assistance. For many, it was more than just support—it was a reminder that their service had not been forgotten.

The atmosphere was one of dignity and mutual respect. Volunteers moved with purpose, service providers worked with compassion, and every interaction was a small act of honoring the immense sacrifices veterans have made for the country.

The All Wars Memorial Building, with its rich history and deep symbolism, provided a fitting venue. It stood not just as a backdrop, but as a testament to the bravery and resilience of the men and women being served within its walls.

Mayor Small emphasized that caring for veterans is more than just a good deed—it’s a responsibility. "Taking care of our veterans isn’t just important—it’s our duty," he shared during the event, reinforcing the message that gratitude must be backed by meaningful action.

City staff and partnering agencies worked side by side to ensure that every veteran felt seen, supported, and valued. These efforts reflect Atlantic City’s broader mission to create a community where all individuals—especially those who have sacrificed for others—are treated with respect and care.

The South Jersey Regional Stand Down was not a one-day gesture, but part of a deeper, continuing commitment to Atlantic City’s veterans. It was a clear demonstration that when local government, service providers, and volunteers come together, lives can be changed.

As the day came to a close, the sense of connection and community lingered. The City of Atlantic City walked away not only having offered services, but having made a powerful statement: our veterans matter, and we will continue to stand with them.

‍

Credit: Ed Lea / City of Atlantic City

item.title: Atlantic City Departments Completed Advanced FEMA Emergency Management Training
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City successfully completed a FEMA-led emergency management training, enhancing response coordination across key departments. This vital training strengthened our city's readiness for large-scale events and emergency situations.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City recently completed a vital emergency management training course led by the FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency and delivered by the New Jersey Incident Management Team under the New Jersey State Police.

Held last week, the hands-on training brought together our Public Safety and Law Enforcement agencies, along with other City departments that respond to emergencies and manage large-scale special events. Participants included the Atlantic City Police Department and the Atlantic City Office of Emergency Management.

This intensive course focused on improving interdepartmental coordination, strategic decision-making, and real-time response to emergency scenarios. It emphasized the importance of trained leadership to ensure faster response times, clearer communication, and safer outcomes for everyone in Atlantic City.

Realistic drills and scenario-based exercises allowed teams to strengthen their operational readiness, resource management, and unified command techniques.

By completing this training, Atlantic City is now better prepared to respond quickly and effectively when emergencies strike. This initiative reflects our continued investment in public safety and commitment to protecting the people of our city.

‍

Credit: Ed Lea / City of Atlantic City

item.title: Creative Bloom: Succulent Terrarium Craft Day at Atlantic City Senior Services
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: Participants at Atlantic City Senior Services created their own succulent terrariums during this month’s Third Thursday craft session. Everyone left with a beautiful masterpiece and a smile.
item.content:encoded:
On the Third Thursday of the month, Atlantic City Senior Services hosted another successful installment of its Monthly Craft Project. This time, participants immersed themselves in the charming world of Succulent Terrariums. The hands-on activity brought together creativity, relaxation, and community bonding in a warm and welcoming environment.

The room was abuzz with excitement as seniors gathered around the craft tables, each station thoughtfully prepared with glass containers, decorative stones, potting soil, and a vibrant selection of succulents. Guided by our friendly staff, attendees learned how to carefully layer materials and thoughtfully arrange their miniature gardens.

The beauty of the terrarium project was not just in the final product, but in the process itself. Seniors shared stories, laughed, and offered each other design tips as they worked on their creations. For many, it was a nostalgic return to gardening, while for others, it was an exciting new experience.

Each terrarium became a unique reflection of its creator—some whimsical, others minimalist, but all bursting with life and color. The joy and sense of accomplishment on everyone’s faces were unmistakable as they proudly displayed their finished pieces.

This month's craft day underscored the importance of creativity in senior wellness programs. Engaging in artistic projects like this not only strengthens motor skills and mental sharpness, but also fosters a deep sense of purpose and social connection.

The event concluded with a group photo, showcasing all the beautiful masterpieces crafted during the session. Participants left not only with their terrariums in hand but with cherished memories and new friendships.

item.title: Atlantic City High School Crew Teams Make History at County Championships
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City High School girls and boys crew teams delivered a dominant performance at the Atlantic County Crew Championships, capturing the combined team points title and several individual and group victories. The event marked a historic day for the program and highlighted its rising strength.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City High School girls and boys crew teams made an indelible mark on Sunday, May 11, 2025, by winning the combined team points title at the Atlantic County Crew Championships, held at Lake Lenape in Mays Landing. It was a defining moment for a program that had been steadily climbing back to prominence in recent seasons.

The girls team captured the highest points trophy of the meet, a reflection of consistent excellence across multiple events. Coach Sean Duffey praised the squad for their work ethic and dedication. “We put a lot of time in out on the water, and it’s great to see it pay off at the end of the year when it counts,” he said. Duffey called it the most significant day in the school’s history at the Atlantic County races.

A major highlight was the girls varsity eight crew’s commanding victory in the 1,500-meter race, finishing in just 5 minutes, 11.6 seconds. The lineup — Mardiha Ahmed, Katelynn Do, Maggie Morgan, Zuzanna Turska, Anna Tran, Jodi-Lynn Pereira, Lauren Fox, stroke Lexi Gormley, and coxswain Tasnova Tayeba — demonstrated unmatched synchronization and strength, achieving the program’s first-ever win in that event.

The day’s success extended beyond a single race. The girls freshman eight clinched a win, signaling that the program’s future remains bright. Meanwhile, the girls varsity second eight added to the medal tally, reinforcing the team’s competitive depth.

Individual prowess also shone through. The girls varsity single sculler brought home a win, showcasing strength and resilience. In another strong performance, the girls varsity quad boat finished first, adding yet another feather to the team's cap.

Not to be outdone, the boys crew team contributed significant victories. The boys second varsity four raced to a win, while the boys novice eight also claimed first place — a testament to the hard work of athletes and coaches alike.

Behind the team’s resurgence was a major investment from the Atlantic City Board of Education, which provided six brand-new Vespoli High Performance Series racing boats, along with new oars and team apparel. The equipment upgrade, revealed in a March 26, 2024 ceremony, helped elevate the program after years of using aging gear.

The new Vespoli boats, with their carbon fiber hulls, wing rigger systems, and custom paintwork, gave ACHS rowers a competitive edge. Coach Duffey noted the significant improvements in both practice and performance. “It was significantly easier to manage practice and races as we were not repairing older, worn-out boats daily,” he said.

This year’s championship victory built on momentum from the previous season, when the girls team won the Junior Eight category at the 2024 Scholastic Rowing Association of America National Championship. With growing numbers, renewed investment, and historic wins under their belt, the ACHS crew teams signaled a powerful comeback and a bright future.

item.title: City of Atlantic City Celebrated Ribbon Cutting of the New Artist Playground at ACX1 Studios
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: As part of Atlantic City’s ongoing support of small businesses, the City proudly celebrated the launch of the Artist Playground at ACX1 Studios—an innovative creative hub dedicated to empowering local talent in podcasts, photography, music, and more.
item.content:encoded:
As the City of Atlantic City continued its celebration of Small Business Month, a key highlight was the ribbon-cutting ceremony for the new Artist Playground at ACX1 Studios. The event brought together community leaders, creatives, and entrepreneurs in a show of support for this dynamic new space designed to serve as a catalyst for local innovation.

The Artist Playground was launched as a multi-functional creative hub, tailored to meet the needs of emerging and established talent in podcasting, photography, music, fashion, live events, and other artistic fields. With its cutting-edge infrastructure and flexible layout, the space was built to inspire collaboration and growth among Atlantic City's creative community.

The ribbon-cutting ceremony was a moment of pride and excitement, as city officials and stakeholders gathered to officially welcome the Artist Playground into Atlantic City’s growing network of small businesses and community-driven initiatives. This new hub aligned perfectly with the City’s #KeepItLocal campaign, which encouraged residents and visitors alike to support and celebrate local entrepreneurs and creators.

The ceremony was more than just an opening—it was a statement of Atlantic City’s ongoing commitment to fostering creativity and economic opportunity through strategic partnerships and investments in cultural spaces.

Local artists, media professionals, and entrepreneurs expressed their excitement for the opportunity to create and collaborate in a space built specifically for them. City representatives emphasized the importance of investing in spaces that provide visibility and support for Atlantic City’s growing creative economy. The City extended its congratulations to all involved in bringing the Artist Playground to life and thanked the community for showing up and supporting this important milestone.

item.title: Atlantic City Launches 'Keep It Local' Campaign and Free Citywide Parking to Celebrate Small Business Month on the 17th
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Atlantic City celebrated Small Business Month with the launch of the ‘Keep it Local’ campaign and a day of FREE CITYWIDE STREET PARKING on May 17 to boost support for local businesses. The initiative highlighted the city’s dedication to making small business growth both accessible and visible.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City officially recognized May as Small Business Month, launching impactful initiatives designed to support local entrepreneurs and boost the city's economic vitality. Mayor Marty Small Sr. issued a proclamation declaring the celebration, reaffirming the city's commitment to its small business community.

At the center of the month-long campaign was the launch of the ‘Keep it Local’ initiative, a citywide effort encouraging residents and visitors to Shop, Eat, Explore in Atlantic City. Spearheaded by the Department of Planning & Development, the campaign aimed to drive foot traffic to local establishments and raise awareness of the diverse businesses that make up the city’s commercial landscape.

Businesses across Atlantic City were provided with eye-catching signage in six vibrant colors—each representing one of the city’s six wards. These signs were placed in storefront windows to show support for the ‘Keep it Local’ message. Participating businesses were also featured on the city’s promotional website, www.greatdayatlanticcity.com, providing added visibility to both residents and tourists.

To further incentivize public engagement, the city declared FREE CITYWIDE STREET PARKING on Saturday, May 17, 2025. Parking meters and kiosks across the city, with the exception of beach block areas, were not enforced, making it easier for people to visit and shop locally. The initiative was a strategic move to remove barriers to access and encourage greater patronage of Atlantic City’s small businesses.

The city’s efforts extended beyond marketing and convenience. The Small Business Academy, a free educational program offered by the city, concluded its latest cohort this month. Residents participated in business pitch sessions and received training on how to start and grow their own businesses—equipping them with essential tools for success.

Additional free programs such as “How to Do Business with Atlantic City” were also made available to residents, offering guidance on navigating city processes and unlocking opportunities for growth and collaboration.

Another important focus was the revitalization of Atlantic Avenue, where the city continued developing a comprehensive incentive package to attract diverse retail businesses, particularly those not currently represented in the community. These efforts aimed to enhance the avenue’s vibrancy and make it a hub for both residents and visitors.

In collaboration with Community Development Corporations (CDC’s) and the Atlantic City Metropolitan Business and Citizens Association (MBCA), the city worked to amplify the impact of the ‘Keep it Local’ campaign. Throughout Small Business Month, Atlantic City underscored its commitment to empowering local businesses through access, visibility, education, and strategic investment. By aligning public initiatives with private-sector goals, the city created a model for community-driven economic development.

item.title: Atlantic City Promotes Officers to Supervisory Roles in Police Department Ceremony
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Mayor Marty Small Sr. administered the Oath of Office to seven Atlantic City Police Department officers who were promoted to supervisory ranks. The ceremony honored their dedication and marked a new chapter in their service to the community.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City Government recently held a formal ceremony to recognize and promote several distinguished members of the Atlantic City Police Department. The event, led by Mayor Marty Small Sr., marked a significant milestone in the careers of the officers honored.

In a momentous display of achievement and leadership, Mayor Small administered the Oath of Office to seven officers who were elevated to supervisory positions within the department. These promotions reflect both their commitment to public service and their readiness to take on greater responsibilities.

Three officers were promoted to the rank of Lieutenant of Police: Daniel Arra, Darrin Lorady, and Michael Garofalo. Each of these individuals has demonstrated exemplary service, leadership, and dedication to the safety and wellbeing of Atlantic City residents.

Additionally, four officers were promoted to the rank of Sergeant of Police: Sean Pettit, Robert Toscano, George King, and Ermindo Marsini. Their promotions acknowledge years of service and their ability to lead and support their fellow officers in challenging and dynamic environments.

The ceremony, attended by colleagues, friends, and family, was a proud moment not only for the honorees but also for the community they serve. It emphasized the city’s continued commitment to building a strong, experienced, and reliable police force.

Mayor Small commended each of the promoted officers for their dedication and professionalism, stating that their advancement reflects both personal merit and the evolving needs of the department.

The newly promoted lieutenants and sergeants are expected to take on enhanced roles in mentoring junior officers, shaping departmental strategy, and upholding the highest standards of law enforcement.

The Atlantic City Police Department continues to invest in leadership development and career progression, ensuring that those who rise through the ranks are prepared to meet the demands of modern policing.

This round of promotions serves as a reminder of the importance of recognizing talent within the force and supporting those who dedicate their lives to serving the community.

The city congratulated all the officers and wished them success as they embark on the next chapter of their careers in law enforcement.

item.title: Community Came Together for Flood Safety Workshop in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City residents gathered for a Flood Safety Workshop on May 7 to learn how to better prepare for emergencies caused by flooding and climate change. The event highlighted the importance of emergency preparedness and community collaboration in the face of rising environmental risks.
item.content:encoded:
On May 7, the City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services successfully hosted a Flood Safety Workshop aimed at educating community members about the growing risks of flooding and how to stay prepared. The workshop was held in partnership with local and state emergency experts, drawing a strong turnout from concerned residents.

Participants gained valuable insights into the causes of flooding, including the increasing impact of climate change and rising sea levels on Atlantic City's flood risk. Experts explained how these environmental shifts are making the region more vulnerable and why it's essential for residents to take proactive measures.

The event also focused on practical strategies for emergency preparedness. Attendees were shown how to protect their homes, families, and belongings in the event of a flood, from creating safety kits to understanding evacuation protocols.

A key highlight of the workshop was the presentation by the Atlantic City Office of Emergency Management, where residents learned about the city's role during natural disasters and how the department coordinates responses to keep the public safe.

The session featured expert speakers including Stephen Holman II and Matthew Baumgardner from the NJ Department of Environmental Protection, who shared data and strategies related to flood management and climate resilience.

In addition, Fire Chief Scott K. Evans and Battalion Chief Michael S. Famularo shared firsthand perspectives on emergency response and fire safety during flooding events, reinforcing the importance of coordinated planning and communication.

The Bangladesh Association of South Jersey played a crucial role in hosting the event and ensuring it ran smoothly, providing a welcoming space for open dialogue and community education.

The workshop not only informed but also empowered residents by equipping them with the knowledge and tools to respond confidently to flood-related emergencies.

City officials expressed their gratitude to everyone who attended and participated in the conversation. Events like this underscore the importance of building a safer, more resilient, and informed community.

As climate-related challenges grow more urgent, Atlantic City remains committed to providing resources and educational opportunities that help its residents stay protected and prepared.

item.title: Atlantic City Free Public Library Unveils New Little Library at Brown’s Park
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Free Public Library introduced a new Little Library at Brown’s Park during the Midtown CDC’s Spring Community Event on May 8. This community initiative was made possible through generous support from local partners.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Free Public Library took another step toward community enrichment with the unveiling of its newest Little Library at Brown’s Park. The ribbon-cutting took place on May 8 during the Midtown Atlantic City CDC’s Spring Community Event, a gathering that brought neighbors together to celebrate growth and connection in Midtown.

The new Little Library stands as a vibrant symbol of literacy, accessibility, and community spirit. Filled with books for all ages and interests, it encourages visitors to take a book or leave one, making it easier for everyone—especially families and children—to access reading materials close to home.

This initiative was part of the Library’s broader effort to promote reading beyond the walls of its main branch. By placing these small, self-serve book hubs in parks and neighborhoods, the library hopes to inspire more people to develop a love of reading in their everyday environments.

The addition of the Little Library was made possible by generous funding from the Foundation of the Atlantic City Free Public Library, AtlantiCare, and the Midtown CDC. Their combined support ensured not just the installation of the unit, but also its continued maintenance and restocking.

Throughout the afternoon, families stopped by to browse the shelves, pick out books, and talk with library staff about upcoming programs and services. Children’s laughter echoed through the park as they explored the new addition, already making it a cherished neighborhood feature.

Representatives from all three funding partners were present, highlighting the collaborative nature of the project. They emphasized how partnerships between nonprofits, health organizations, and civic groups are essential to building stronger, more informed communities.

The Atlantic City Free Public Library has long been committed to outreach and inclusion, and the launch of this Little Library is just the latest example of that mission in action. It not only provides a practical resource but also fosters a sense of pride and ownership within the neighborhood.

As the event wound down, visitors left with books in hand and smiles on their faces. The success of the launch demonstrated the impact that small, thoughtful investments can have in shaping a more connected and literate Atlantic City.

Looking ahead, the library plans to expand its Little Library program to other neighborhoods, ensuring that the joy of reading reaches every corner of the city. With continued support from community partners, this initiative will serve as a long-lasting resource for residents of all ages.

item.title: Atlantic City Entrepreneurs Take the Stage at Small Business Academy Pitch Day
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: On May 8th, aspiring Atlantic City entrepreneurs presented their business ideas after completing the 10-week Small Business Academy. The program gave participants tools, guidance, and confidence to turn their business dreams into action.
item.content:encoded:
The energy at Simpson’s Restaurant on Thursday, May 8th, was undeniable as aspiring entrepreneurs from across Atlantic City stepped up to pitch their business ideas to a panel of judges. These participants had just completed the Small Business Academy, a free, intensive 10-week program designed to empower local residents with the knowledge and resources to launch or expand their own businesses.

The room was filled with excitement, nerves, and hope. Each participant had spent weeks immersed in the fundamentals of business operations, from financial planning and branding to market research and growth strategies. The academy was led by Bruce Weekes and Pam Fields of the City of Atlantic City’s Planning and Development Department, in collaboration with the African American Chamber of Commerce of New Jersey.

The pitch competition served as the culmination of everything the participants had learned. Presenters shared their vision in front of a panel made up of local business owners and investors, offering not only feedback but potential support and partnerships. Some participants came in with existing businesses they wanted to scale, while others were presenting a brand-new concept for the first time.

The ideas were as diverse and vibrant as the city itself, ranging from new restaurants to mom-and-pop shops to innovative service-based businesses. No matter the concept, each pitch reflected a shared determination: to contribute something valuable to the local economy and community.

The Small Business Academy wasn’t just about education, it was about empowerment. For many participants, this was their first time standing in a room of professionals and publicly expressing a business vision. The confidence they displayed was a testament to the strength of the program and the support they received along the way.

Mayor Marty Small, Sr., who created the academy several years ago, has long championed initiatives that support local development and economic opportunity. His vision for the academy was simple but impactful: give Atlantic City residents real tools to help them succeed in the competitive world of business.

The evening highlighted how much potential exists when communities invest in their own people. The judges, visibly impressed, offered constructive feedback, mentorship opportunities, and in some cases, real interest in funding or supporting the pitches they heard.

While not every idea may launch tomorrow, the seeds were clearly planted. Participants walked away not only with experience, but with momentum and a network of mentors, peers, and advocates cheering them on.

In the weeks and months ahead, many of these aspiring entrepreneurs will take the next steps in making their ideas a reality. Thanks to the Small Business Academy, they’ll be doing it with knowledge, confidence, and community backing.

The future of Atlantic City’s small business landscape looks brighter than ever, powered by passion, preparation, and people ready to build something great.

item.title: Atlantic City Police Unity Tour Rolls Through Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Police Unity Tour made a moving stop in Atlantic City on May 12th, bringing together law enforcement officers and surviving families to honor those who gave their lives in the line of duty. The city stood still as riders arrived in solemn unity and deep respect.
item.content:encoded:
Every year, the Police Unity Tour brings together riders from across the country—men and women in law enforcement, along with survivors of line-of-duty deaths—for one deeply meaningful mission: to honor their fallen colleagues. This year was no different, and on May 12th, at exactly 2:00 PM, the tour made a poignant stop in Atlantic City, drawing the attention and admiration of the community.

The streets were lined with residents and supporters who came out to witness a moment of collective remembrance. What made this gathering powerful was not just the presence of flashing lights or the formation of bicycles rolling in—it was the silent, unspoken connection among the riders and the families they ride for. Every face in the crowd reflected a mix of solemnity, pride, and gratitude.

The Police Unity Tour isn’t just about a bike ride—it’s about carrying a legacy forward. Each participant rides in memory of someone lost too soon, many wearing badges or patches displaying the names of those they honor. As they moved through Atlantic City, you could feel the weight of every mile they had already covered, and the purpose behind every pedal stroke.

After their arrival, the riders were welcomed with a brief but heartfelt ceremony. Speakers from the tour organization, local government, and survivor networks shared words that resonated deeply with everyone present. The message was simple yet powerful: those who have made the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty will never be forgotten.

One of the most touching moments came when families of fallen officers were invited forward. Their stories were short, but each one painted a vivid picture of courage, commitment, and love for service. The crowd stood in respectful silence as names were read, and the memory of each officer was brought to life again through stories, smiles, and even tears.

The event also served a broader purpose beyond remembrance. The Police Unity Tour raises awareness and funds for the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial and Museum in Washington, D.C., ensuring that these stories are preserved for generations to come. The riders’ dedication to the cause reminded everyone that honoring the past also means educating the future.

Atlantic City has long stood as a symbol of strength and resilience, and hosting the Police Unity Tour only reinforced that spirit. The city's officials, including Mayor Marty Small Sr., extended their gratitude to the participants and emphasized the city’s unwavering support for its public servants and their families.

What lingered after the crowd dispersed wasn’t just the memory of flashing lights and uniforms, but the emotional impact of unity. For many in attendance, especially those who have lost someone in the line of duty, it was a day of healing and connection. It reminded everyone that they are not alone.

As the tour continued on its journey, Atlantic City was left with a deep sense of appreciation and honor. The moment may have passed, but the message remained: service is never forgotten, and sacrifice is always remembered.

The Police Unity Tour left an indelible mark not just on the streets of the city, but on the hearts of all who witnessed it.

item.title: Atlantic City High School Collected Over 30 Pints of Blood Thanks to One Student’s Power Red Donation
item.dc:creator: Christina Noble and Tasha Devonish
item.description: Atlantic City High School collected over 30 pints of blood during its spring blood drive on May 7, 2025, highlighted by Derek Santos making a Power Red donation. Students’ efforts directly helped those in need and inspired future community involvement.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City High School American Red Cross Blood Drive made an impressive impact on May 7, 2025, with students coming together to support a life-saving cause. One standout contribution came from junior Derek Santos, who went beyond a standard blood donation by making a Power Red donation, collecting two units of red blood cells in a single appointment.

Derek Santos was inspired by his biomedical science class, where he had been learning the intricacies of drawing blood. Motivated by a challenge from his teacher, he embraced the opportunity, saying, “It’s a cool opportunity. I feel like I did my good deed for the day.” His action exemplified how young people can make a significant difference through small, courageous steps.

A Power Red donation differs from a traditional blood donation by returning platelets, plasma, and saline to the donor after collecting the red blood cells. Although the process took longer, it was twice as effective in terms of impact, making Santos’s donation even more meaningful.

The blood drive was organized by Jaclyn Sarnese and Bryan Scheeler at Atlantic City High School. Jaclyn Sarnese, a biomedical science teacher, emphasized that the students should feel proud of their participation, as their efforts would directly help people in urgent need. Bryan Scheeler, the Red Cross Club advisor, noted that Atlantic City High School traditionally held blood drives each winter and spring.

This year’s spring event surpassed expectations, with students donating more than 30 pints of blood, outdoing the collection from the previous January blood drive. The overwhelming response demonstrated the students' generosity, compassion, and community spirit.

Scheeler also expressed hope that student volunteers would gain valuable insight into the broader work of organizations like the American Red Cross and recognize future opportunities for involvement and service.

The successful event proved that when students are given the right encouragement and opportunities, they can come together to achieve something truly remarkable. Atlantic City High School once again showed that service and education go hand in hand.

The Atlantic City High School American Red Cross Blood Drive served as a shining example of student leadership, volunteerism, and commitment to saving lives.

item.title: Atlantic City Celebrates ‘Small Business Month’ with New Initiatives Including Free Parking on May 17th
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The City of Atlantic City celebrated Small Business Month in May 2025 by launching initiatives such as the Free Parking on May 17 event and the ‘Keep it Local’ campaign. These efforts were designed to promote local businesses and boost the city’s economy.
item.content:encoded:
In honor of National Small Business Month, the City of Atlantic City officially celebrated Small Business Month throughout May 2025. Mayor Marty Small Sr. delivered a proclamation affirming the city's commitment to supporting local businesses and boosting the local economy.

The Department of Planning & Development, under the leadership of Assistant Director of Economic Development Bruce Weekes and Principal Community Organizational Specialist Pam Fields, launched a series of initiatives designed to empower small businesses across Atlantic City. Their efforts demonstrated the city’s dedication to creating a thriving environment for entrepreneurs and local commerce.

On May 17, 2025, the city offered Free Parking on May 17, waiving parking fees at meters and kiosks throughout Atlantic City, except on the beach blocks. This initiative encouraged both residents and visitors to explore the city and support neighborhood businesses without the concern of parking fees.

The city also introduced the ‘Keep it Local’ campaign, featuring colorful signage encouraging people to ‘Shop, Eat, Explore’ Atlantic City. Each sign’s color represented one of the city's six wards. Businesses that displayed the signage were featured on the city’s newly launched website — www.greatdayatlanticcity.com — further boosting their visibility.

The Small Business Academy continued to provide free education and training for Atlantic City residents interested in launching or expanding their businesses. The latest cohort graduated in May 2025, and participants showcased their business pitches at The Simpson Restaurant and Bar.

In addition to the academy, the city offered other valuable free programs, such as “How to Do Business with Atlantic City,” helping residents understand the processes and resources available to them.

As part of a larger revitalization effort, the city worked on a comprehensive incentive package to encourage new businesses to open along Atlantic Avenue. The goal was to increase vibrancy, attract businesses currently lacking in the area, such as a hardware store — and enhance the overall experience for residents and visitors.

The City of Atlantic City also strengthened community partnerships by collaborating with local Community Development Corporations (CDCs) and the Atlantic City Metropolitan Business and Citizens Association (MBCA). These organizations provides grants and resources to help new businesses get their start, reinforcing the city’s mission to grow a robust, local economy.

item.title: Atlantic City Hosted Flood Safety Workshop for Local Residents
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services held a Flood Safety workshop at the Bangladesh Association of South Jersey Community Center, equipping residents with critical knowledge and free preparedness kits. Emergency officials and environmental experts delivered key safety tips to help the community respond effectively during flood events.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services successfully organized a Flood Safety workshop this past week to educate residents about emergency preparedness in the event of flooding. The workshop was held at the Bangladesh Association of South Jersey Community Center, bringing important information directly to the local community.

The event featured presentations from several key experts, including Scott Evans, Coordinator of the Atlantic City Office of Emergency Management, Battalion Chief Michael Famularo from the Atlantic City OEM, and Stephen Holman, an Environmental Specialist with the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection (NJDEP).

These professionals provided practical insights on flood preparedness, response strategies, and community safety measures. The speakers emphasized the importance of readiness before emergencies strike and encouraged residents to take preventive actions now.

Attendees were advised to always have a plan in place in case of flooding, ensuring that their households and emergency supplies are ready in advance. Officials also stressed the life-saving importance of not ignoring evacuation orders, as timely action can prevent injury or worse during flood events.

Another key message delivered during the workshop was the necessity of having a go-bag or emergency kit prepared. This can include items such as bottled water, essential medications, flashlights, important documents, and emergency contact numbers.

In support of this advice, all attendees were provided with free flooding preparedness kits, ensuring that they left the event with both knowledge and practical tools to increase their safety at home.

This initiative reflected the city's growing focus on inclusive outreach, particularly through its Multicultural Services division, which continues to partner with community organizations to deliver valuable resources to Atlantic City’s diverse population.

The collaboration with the Bangladesh Association of South Jersey helped to ensure the workshop reached a vital and engaged segment of the community, making the effort both culturally responsive and impactful.

By bringing together emergency management professionals, environmental specialists, and community members, the event fostered a strong sense of preparedness and collective responsibility.

Atlantic City’s proactive approach to public safety education, especially in the face of climate-related risks, further demonstrates its commitment to protecting all residents through informed planning and accessible support.

item.title: City of Atlantic City Empowers Local Small Businesses in May
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City celebrates Small Business Month this May with a series of impactful programs and announcements led by Mayor Small. From waived parking fees to new campaigns and incentives, the city placed local businesses at the forefront of economic development.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City took significant strides to support its entrepreneurial community by celebrating Small Business Month this past May. Under the leadership of Mayor Small, the city government launched a series of initiatives designed to promote, develop, and uplift local businesses. This announcement aligned with the national observance of Small Business Month and Small Business Week, and it was a momentous step in highlighting the essential role small businesses play in the local economy.

Mayor Small officially proclaimed May as Small Business Month in Atlantic City, emphasizing the city's commitment to economic empowerment. The City of Atlantic City - Government, through the Planning & Development Department led by Bruce Weekes and Pam Fields, spearheaded several key programs and collaborations throughout the month.

One of the notable actions was the city's decision to waive parking enforcement at meters and kiosks across Atlantic City on Saturday, May 17, with the exception of beach block areas. This move was intended to increase accessibility and encourage more foot traffic to small businesses during weekend shopping hours.

The city also launched its ‘Keep it Local’ campaign, aimed at fostering a sense of community by encouraging residents and visitors to shop and engage with local businesses. This campaign tied into the celebration of Great Day Atlantic City, an event showcasing the spirit and offerings of local entrepreneurs.

Another significant development included a comprehensive incentive package in the works to attract new businesses to Atlantic Avenue, one of the city’s key commercial corridors. These incentives aimed to make it easier and more appealing for new entrepreneurs to establish and grow their ventures in Atlantic City.

In addition to these efforts, the city strengthened partnerships with local Community Development Corporations (CDCs), including Inlet Community Development Corporation, Midtown Atlantic City CDC, Ducktown AC, Chelsea EDC, and MBCA AC. These collaborations allowed the city to leverage shared resources to support business development and neighborhood revitalization.

Education and empowerment were also major components of this initiative. The city continued to offer free programs to residents through the Atlantic City Small Business Academy, which has become a hub for cultivating the next generation of entrepreneurs. Participants in the academy had the opportunity to develop and present their business pitches, fostering innovation and confidence among future business leaders.

Through these collective efforts, Atlantic City demonstrated a firm commitment to revitalizing its economic landscape. By investing in its people and its neighborhoods, the city not only celebrated small business but also planted the seeds for long-term, sustainable growth.

item.title: Atlantic City Celebrated Visit AC Day on May 7 in Recognition of Tourism Excellence
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City officially declared May 7, 2025, as Visit Atlantic City Day to celebrate Visit Atlantic City's record-breaking contributions to tourism and economic growth. Highlights included a special Volunteer Day in partnership with South Jersey Field of Dreams and the announcement of more than $77 million in economic impact.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City officially declared May 7, 2025, as Visit Atlantic City Day in celebration of National Travel and Tourism Week. The proclamation honored Visit Atlantic City's significant contributions to the city's economic growth and recognized its vital role in strengthening Atlantic City's status as a premier destination.

During the first quarter of 2025, Visit Atlantic City generated more than $77 million in economic impact by hosting 12 major conventions, sporting events, and conferences. This achievement fueled the city's year-round tourism and set a new benchmark for success in the region.

The proclamation also acknowledged the strategic integration of Visit Atlantic City with DO AC and the leadership of President and CEO Gary Musich. His vision and direction further solidified Atlantic City's reputation as a thriving travel and tourism hub.

Gary Musich expressed gratitude for the honor, emphasizing the ongoing reinvestment into Atlantic City's casino resorts, entertainment offerings, culinary scene, and unique visitor experiences. His commitment to continued momentum was shared by the organization's destination partners.

Among its recent milestones, Visit Atlantic City preserved and reimagined major events, including the transformation of the iconic Atlantic City Airshow into the Visit Atlantic City Soar & Shore Festival, enhancing the city's vibrant events calendar.

item.title: Atlantic City Senior Services Reflected on a Special Trip to "Stompin' at The Savoy"
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services' Fun and Fitness Class took a day off from their usual exercise routine to attend the lively stage play Stompin' at The Savoy in Wilmington, Delaware, enjoying a memorable trip into the golden age of swing. The experience combined history, music, and community spirit.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Senior Services took a break from their usual routine and embarked on a special trip filled with culture and history. The weekly Fun and Fitness Class, usually led by Terri Bethea of T. Diamond Fitness, took a day off from exercising and traveled to Wilmington, Delaware.

The group attended the vibrant, music-infused stage play Stompin' at The Savoy. The performance transported everyone back to the golden age of swing, bringing to life the story of Norma Miller, The Lindy Hoppers, and the legendary Savoy Ballroom in Harlem.

The experience offered not just entertainment but also a deep appreciation for the cultural history of swing dance and the Harlem Renaissance. The lively music, energetic dance numbers, and engaging storytelling captured the spirit of a truly transformative era.

For many participants, it was more than just a show — it was a walk through history that reignited memories and created new moments to cherish.

Atlantic City Senior Services expressed gratitude for the opportunity to combine fun, learning, and community building outside of their regular classes.

The outing reinforced the program’s commitment to providing enriching experiences that promote both mental and physical wellness for the city's senior residents.

Following the trip, participants returned home inspired and energized, looking forward to future activities that blend health, culture, and connection.

The weekly Fun and Fitness Class continues to meet every Tuesday at 5 PM, offering seniors a supportive and engaging space to stay active and connected.

For more information on how to join the class or upcoming special events, residents are encouraged to call 609-347-5458.

item.title: Mayor Small Announced New Location and Updates for Atlantic City's BRT Weekend
item.description: Mayor Marty Small, Sr. announced that this summer’s BRT Weekend successfully took place on Missouri Avenue Beach instead of Chelsea Avenue Beach, reflecting a new approach to event planning in Atlantic City. Discussions about the future of the Chelsea Beach Bar also began during this time.
item.content:encoded:
Mayor Marty Small, Sr. officially announced changes for this summer’s highly anticipated BRT Weekend in Atlantic City. The weekend-long music festival, originally expected to take place on Chelsea Avenue Beach in front of the Ocean Club Condominiums, was relocated to Missouri Avenue Beach. The event successfully ran from July 11-13, drawing crowds to the new venue.

During the announcement, Mayor Small also stated that no large or medium-scale events would be held on the beach in front of the Ocean Club moving forward. This decision reflected the City's commitment to addressing concerns from local residents and ensuring the best possible experience for visitors and homeowners alike.

In addition to the event relocation, the City entered early discussions regarding the future of the Chelsea Beach Bar. Officials considered permanently moving the popular bar to another Boardwalk location. However, for the summer season, the Chelsea Beach Bar continued to operate from its existing site under its current lease.

The relocation to Missouri Avenue Beach provided a larger, more central space for festival-goers, contributing to improved traffic flow, security measures, and overall guest experience during BRT Weekend.

Mayor Small emphasized the City's focus on sustainable event planning, community responsiveness, and preserving Atlantic City’s beach areas for the enjoyment of all residents and visitors.

City officials also pointed out that while permanent decisions about Chelsea Beach Bar were still under discussion, they aimed to create a plan that balanced the needs of the business community with the quality of life of nearby residents.

The successful hosting of BRT Weekend at Missouri Avenue Beach set a positive precedent for future large-scale events in Atlantic City. Feedback from attendees, businesses, and local leaders was overwhelmingly supportive of the new location.

Looking ahead, Atlantic City’s administration remains committed to proactive event management, transparency with residents, and fostering a vibrant summer experience for everyone.

Mayor Small’s leadership and the City’s quick adjustments were credited with ensuring another memorable and safe summer in Atlantic City.
