item.title: Atlantic City Community Treasure: Ralph Hunter of the African American Heritage Museum of Southern New Jersey
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The African American Heritage Museum of Southern New Jersey founder and president Ralph Hunter on receiving another well-deserved honor. His accomplishments continue to benefit Atlantic City, South Jersey, and the wider community.
item.content:encoded:
A Living Archive: Ralph Hunter Sr. and the Legacy of Black History in Atlantic City

When you walk through the African American Heritage Museum of Southern New Jersey, you’re not just viewing history, you’re stepping into the life’s work of Ralph Hunter Sr., a man whose quiet dedication has helped preserve thousands of untold stories.

At 87 years old, Mr. Hunter is still preserving the history many have overlooked. Founder of the museum, which operates locations in both Atlantic City and Buena Vista Township, he has built one of the region’s most important cultural institutions from the ground up. What began as a personal passion project has evolved into a collection of more than 33,000 pieces, documenting the lives, legacies, and contributions of African Americans throughout South Jersey and beyond.

Only 5% of the collection is on display at any given time. Imagine that decades of Black history, hidden in plain sight.

Mr. Hunter’s journey began with a curiosity and a sense of responsibility. His early experience working with renowned collector Herman Blum planted a seed, and by 2002, that seed grew into the opening of the first African American Heritage Museum in Newtonville. The Atlantic City branch followed, now housed in the Noyes Arts Garage of Stockton University, where thousands of visitors, local and global, come to learn about the rich heritage of the city’s Black community.

From artifacts and photographs to rare memorabilia, each item in the museum has a story and Mr. Hunter knows many of them by heart. He has welcomed over 20,000 visitors annually through the doors of the museum and reached more than 100,000 students through his mobile museum exhibits, which travel across New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, and New York.

"People say to me, 'We didn’t know there was any history in Atlantic City,'" Mr. Hunter shared. His mission has always been to change that.

This commitment to truth, education, and cultural preservation is why Mr. Hunter is honored with the 2025 Spirit of Hospitality Award by the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority (CRDA). It is a recognition long overdue for a man who has given so much of himself to ensure others never feel forgotten.

As Mr. Hunter shared in his video spotlight, "More and more people have to learn that when they come to a town like Atlantic City, to learn the history. And that’s what we do here at the African American Heritage Museum."

We are proud to feature Mr. Hunter on Great Day Atlantic City to ensure that his contributions are shared, celebrated, and remembered.

item.title: Pop Lloyd Stadium Reopens: A Tribute to Atlantic City History and a Gift to the Future
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Pop Lloyd Stadium in Atlantic City officially reopened on Tuesday, April 29th, following a $5.6 million renovation that transformed the historic site into a vibrant, multi-sport facility for future generations.
item.content:encoded:
With cheers from the community and pride from city leaders, Pop Lloyd Stadium officially reopened on Tuesday following a $5.6 million renovation that transformed the historic site into a vibrant, multi-sport facility for future generations.

The ribbon-cutting ceremony marked not just the reopening of a field, but the revival of a legacy. Named in honor of Hall of Famer and Negro League legend John Henry “Pop” Lloyd, the stadium now stands as a living monument to both Atlantic City’s deep-rooted Black history and its ongoing investment in community.

Mayor Marty Small Sr., joined by local officials and residents, addressed the crowd at home plate with heartfelt conviction. He shared that the vision for this transformation began on November 8, 2019, when he first committed to turning the aging stadium into a state-of-the-art, multi-purpose complex.

“This is a gift for the community,” he said.

‍

The renovation, funded largely through the American Rescue Plan, replaced overgrown grass and a deteriorated infield with a gleaming navy blue artificial turf, accented with bright red infield markings. The revitalized stadium now features new bleachers, dugouts, lighting, a scoreboard, sound system, locker rooms, restrooms, and fencing. It is equipped to host baseball, softball, flag football, and other sports, serving local residents while attracting regional play.

“This is how government should work,” said Councilman Kaleem Shabazz. “Pop Lloyd is part of American history. If there wasn’t segregation and discrimination, he would’ve been a Major League star. This stadium is not just a baseball field, it’s part of our country’s history. We have a solemn duty to tell his story and preserve this legacy.”

Born in 1884, John Henry “Pop” Lloyd was one of the greatest shortstops in Negro League history. After his playing career, he worked as a custodian in Atlantic City’s public schools and was remembered for his humility, mentorship, and enduring presence in the community.

Ron Jordan, 90, a longtime resident and Indiana Avenue School alum, recalled meeting Lloyd in his youth.

“As time went on, I learned just how much he contributed to baseball,” Jordan said, noting that he later visited the National Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., to see Lloyd’s plaque.

Jordan then introduced Pedro Sierra, 86, a former Negro Leagues pitcher from Cuba who also played in the minor leagues for the Minnesota Twins and Washington Senators.

“I’m thankful for all the men who came before me and opened doors for players like me,” Sierra shared.

‍

The relaunch of Pop Lloyd Stadium is part of Mayor Small’s broader strategy to reinvest in Atlantic City’s public assets. Just weeks ago, the city celebrated the reopening of the Atlantic City Aquarium, another revitalization project funded by the federal COVID-19 relief package.

City Business Administrator Anthony Swan reminded attendees that stewardship is key to sustainability. “We spent a lot of time, money, and effort to bring this to the community. Let’s protect it.”

For Mike Griffin, Director of Recreation, the reopening held deep personal meaning. “I grew up riding my bike past this stadium, watching casino leagues play, and even playing ball here as a student,” he said.
“Now I get to oversee this field for the next generation. It’s a full-circle moment.”

Since Mayor Small declared the stadium “open for business,” Griffin said the Recreation Department has been flooded with calls. The first event—a high school baseball game between Atlantic City and Oakcrest—is scheduled for Thursday, May 1st. Adult softball leagues and other recreational programs will follow this summer.

“This is going to be something that doesn’t exist anywhere else in South Jersey,” Griffin said.

‍

‍

The reopening of Pop Lloyd Stadium restores a beloved landmark, honors the past, and opens new doors for Atlantic City’s future. A field of dreams once again, ready for a new generation to step up to the plate.

‍Pop Lloyd Stadium is located next to the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. School on Huron Avenue. The facility is managed by the Atlantic City Recreation Department and is available for public use and event rentals.

item.title: Volunteers Came Together to Beautify Atlantic City's Midtown During April’s Adopt A Block Cleanup
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: Midtown volunteers gathered for a beautiful morning of cleaning and community at the April Adopt A Block event. Participants worked together to revitalize the neighborhood and were rewarded with lunch and community pride.
item.content:encoded:
It was a beautiful morning in Midtown as volunteers gathered for the April edition of the Adopt A Block community cleanup. Residents, local leaders, and volunteers joined forces to help refresh and revitalize the neighborhood, showing their pride and commitment to keeping Atlantic City clean and welcoming.

Organized by the Midtown office, the cleanup drew community members of all ages who contributed their time and energy to picking up litter, sweeping sidewalks, and making Midtown shine. The event not only improved the physical appearance of the area but also fostered a stronger sense of unity and collaboration among participants.

Everyone who took part played a meaningful role in promoting civic responsibility and setting an example for others to follow. Following the cleanup, volunteers were treated to a lunch as a thank-you for their hard work and dedication.

Those who missed this month’s cleanup were encouraged to join the next one, scheduled for May 10th at 10 AM, meeting at 1809 Pacific Ave. The initiative remains a great way to give back and connect with fellow residents.

item.title: Atlantic City Council Honors Student Athlete and Special Events Team for Outstanding Achievements
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: City Council honored Khajuan “Peaky” Roseborough for his record-breaking performance in sports and strong academics, and recognized the Mayor’s Office of Special Events for their standout work on the Aquarium Grand Reopening. Both were celebrated as shining examples of excellence and dedication in Atlantic City.
item.content:encoded:
During the most recent City of Atlantic City - Government City Council meeting, Council members formally recognized Khajuan “Peaky” Roseborough, a standout member of the Atlantic City High School Class of 2025, for his exceptional achievements both on and off the field. Roseborough not only broke records in football and basketball, but also maintained an impressive 3.5 GPA, exemplifying the balance of athletic excellence and academic dedication.

City Council praised Roseborough’s commitment to his education while excelling as a student-athlete, calling him a role model for young people throughout the city. His recognition marked a proud moment for Atlantic City High School and the broader community.

In addition, Council commended the Mayor’s Office of Special Events for their outstanding work organizing major city functions. The team was especially lauded for their stunning decorations and logistical coordination during last month’s Atlantic City Aquarium Grand Reopening, which drew praise from residents and visitors alike.

Their efforts were described as vital to the city’s continued success in hosting vibrant, well-executed public events that highlight Atlantic City’s unique character and culture.

item.title: Mayor Small Highlights Crime Reduction at NOBLE Region I Conference in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Mayor Small and Chief Sarkos addressed national law enforcement leaders at the NOBLE Region I Conference, celebrating an 11-percent drop in crime in Atlantic City. The conference showcased the city's recent public safety successes and its growing role in regional law enforcement leadership.
item.content:encoded:
Mayor Small and Atlantic City Police Department Chief Sarkos were among the featured speakers at the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives (NOBLE) Region I Conference, held at the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Atlantic City. The event brought together law enforcement leadership from across the country for a week of collaboration, dialogue, and strategic planning.

During his address, Mayor Small officially welcomed the distinguished guests and emphasized the importance of unity and innovation in public safety. He also took the opportunity to spotlight the progress being made locally, including a notable 11-percent decrease in crime during the first quarter of 2025 compared to the same period in 2024.

Mayor Small praised the Atlantic City Police Department for its proactive efforts and commitment to community policing, crediting the decrease in crime to strategic partnerships and data-driven approaches. Chief Sarkos also underscored the department’s dedication to transparency and ongoing reform efforts aimed at building public trust.

The presence of national law enforcement leaders, combined with the celebration of Atlantic City’s local achievements, made the conference a meaningful moment of recognition and forward momentum for the city.

item.title: Atlantic City Crime Continues Downward Trend in 2025, First Quarter Data Shows
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The City of Atlantic City is seeing real progress in public safety. According to newly released data from the Atlantic City Police Department (ACPD), overall crime in the city has dropped by more than 11% in the first quarter of 2025 compared to the same period in 2024—another strong signal that the Small administration’s investments in safety and technology are delivering results.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City is seeing real progress in public safety. According to newly released data from the Atlantic City Police Department (ACPD), overall crime in the city has dropped by more than 11% in the first quarter of 2025 compared to the same period in 2024—another strong signal that the Small administration’s investments in safety and technology are delivering results.

The statistics, sourced from the New Jersey State Police Offense Report, show declines across every major crime category:

  • Crimes Against Persons (including homicide, assault, and sex offenses) are down 22.28%
  • Crimes Against Property (including robbery, burglary, and theft) have decreased by 4.3%
  • Crimes Against Society (including drug offenses, weapons offenses, and prostitution) are down 4.48%

In total, Group "A" Offenses fell from 1,427 in Q1 2024 to 1,266 in Q1 2025—an 11.28% decrease overall.

Perhaps most significantly, there were zero homicides reported in the first quarter of 2025, compared to six during the same time last year. Non-fatal shooting incidents are also down. The ACPD investigated just three shooting cases in 2025, versus eight similar incidents in early 2024—a 62.5% reduction.

“There's this exaggerated narrative that Atlantic City is not clean and safe, but the facts and data tell a different story,” said Mayor Marty Small, Sr. “The Atlantic City Police Department keeps showing why they are the best police department in the world. Whether it’s added manpower, new equipment and technology, or promotions, my administration will continue to support law enforcement in every way possible to keep this downward trend in crime going.”

ACPD responded to 24,733 calls for service in the first quarter of 2025—averaging 274 calls per day. That’s a notable decrease from the 26,523 calls for service during the same period in 2024. Arrest totals have remained steady: 1,159 individuals were charged in Q1 2025, nearly identical to last year’s 1,161. However, juvenile arrests have increased, rising from 36 in 2024 to 67 in 2025.

Ongoing initiatives like the Citywide Surveillance Camera Project—now two-thirds complete—are strengthening the city’s crime-fighting tools. New surveillance cameras are coming online each week, improving real-time response, crash analysis, and officer safety.

In addition, the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority (CRDA) has awarded a $3 million grant to expand patrols in the Tourism District through March 2026. Beginning April 1, increased police presence on the Boardwalk and surrounding areas will include five new utility terrain vehicles (UTVs), complementing bicycle and foot patrols for greater visibility and coverage.

“I am excited about the progress we’ve made in the first quarter of 2025 and the future improvements ahead,” said ACPD Chief James A. Sarkos. “With the ongoing hard work and commitment of our officers, our partnerships with the city and community, and the integration of new technologies, I am confident that we will continue to reduce crime and make a lasting impact on public safety in Atlantic City.”

item.title: Mayor Small Unveils 2025 Budget with Continued Tax Reduction and Investor Confidence for Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Atlantic City is charting a new course—and delivering real results. This week, Mayor Marty Small Sr. announced the sixth consecutive property tax decrease for Atlantic City residents, cementing a powerful trend of financial responsibility and resident-focused governance. Unveiled during a news conference at City Hall, the 2025 City of Atlantic City budget includes a 3.4-cent tax rate reduction—a move that not only keeps money in residents’ pockets, but also sends a clear message: this administration is putting people first.
item.content:encoded:
Six straight years of tax decreases reflect strong leadership, community investment, and growing economic momentum.

Atlantic City continues to chart a new path forward—one defined by fiscal responsibility, transparency, and a deep commitment to the people who call it home. This week, Mayor Marty Small Sr. announced the sixth consecutive municipal property tax decrease, part of a $258 million city budget that prioritizes both community needs and long-term financial strength.

The 3.4-cent tax rate cut in the 2025 budget follows years of strategic planning and disciplined budgeting under the Small administration, and is a clear reflection of the city’s core focus: putting residents first while ensuring Atlantic City is a place where families can thrive, businesses can grow, and investors can feel confident.

“This administration is keeping its promise by making the city’s taxpayers its number one priority,” Mayor Small shared during a news conference at City Hall. “Once again, Atlantic City is a leader when it comes to fiscal responsibility.”

Real Relief, Strategic Spending

The 2025 budget includes $258 million in municipal spending, and when including grant funds, totals nearly $280 million. The budget also includes a full payoff of the city’s debt service for the year—a move made possible by years of careful financial management.

According to Chief Financial Officer Toro Aboderin, the city now holds a $78 million surplus, $28 million of which will be used to fund the 2025 budget. The budget also allocates $27 million toward capital improvements, including street paving and building repairs—delivering visible, on-the-ground benefits to Atlantic City residents.

Perhaps even more remarkable: the city’s outstanding debt has dropped from $550 million in 2019 to $328 million today, showing how far the city has come since state oversight began under the 2016 Municipal Stabilization and Revitalization Act.

State Support Driving Down the Levy

One key piece of Atlantic City’s financial turnaround has been its access to Investment Alternative Taxes (IATs)—taxes collected from casino gaming revenues that are now used to help pay down municipal debt. In 2024, the city received over $68 million in IAT funding, thanks to reforms that redirected these revenues from the CRDA back into the city’s general operations.

As a result, Atlantic City’s tax levy has plummeted—from $128 million in 2015 to just $34 million today. Meanwhile, the tax collection rate has improved from roughly 95% in 2019 to 98.1% in 2025—a testament to growing public trust and consistent city leadership.

Credit Ratings and Investor Outlook on the Rise

This momentum has not gone unnoticed. In September, Moody’s Ratings upgraded the city’s long-term issuer rating to Ba2, while Standard & Poor’s raised its rating to BB+. Atlantic City is now just one step away from investment-grade status—a critical milestone that could unlock new funding opportunities and strengthen the city’s ability to attract developers and anchor institutions.

Mayor Small and his finance team, including Business Administrator Anthony Swan, Budget Officer Tom Monoghan, and partners from the Department of Community Affairs, say they are laser-focused on keeping the progress going.

“We’re continuously finding ways to get more money and make our financial situation better,” Small said. “With the plethora of development projects scheduled to come online next year, we’re going to be in a great place to have another tax decrease.”

Why It Matters

For residents, six years of steady tax relief means Atlantic City is becoming a more affordable place to live and raise a family. For businesses and entrepreneurs, it signals smart, stable governance and ongoing investment in infrastructure, safety, and growth. And for investors watching from afar, it’s another reason to believe in Atlantic City’s transformation.

From balancing budgets to backing bold development initiatives like Bader Field, Mayor Small’s administration is demonstrating what it means to lead with both fiscal discipline and a community-first vision.

item.title: Planning with Purpose: Atlantic City Seniors Gained Insight at Lunch & Learn Session
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: The second Lunch & Learn Session of 2025 brought seniors together for an informative presentation on Wills, Trusts, and Estate Planning, led by Anne Crozier of the Bratton Law Firm. Attendees left informed, inspired, and full of both knowledge and lunch.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Senior Services successfully hosted its second Lunch & Learn Session of 2025, offering residents valuable knowledge in a relaxed and welcoming setting. The event was designed to provide both educational enrichment and a sense of community for seniors.

The featured speaker, Anne Crozier of the Bratton Law Firm, led a highly informative discussion focused on Wills, Trusts, and Estate Planning. Her presentation helped attendees better understand their options for preparing and protecting their assets, and sparked thoughtful questions from the audience.

The session offered more than just information—it encouraged open dialogue and empowered participants to consider their long-term plans with greater clarity. The interactive nature of the event allowed for real-time questions and answers, ensuring that everyone left with a deeper understanding of the topics discussed.

Following the presentation, attendees enjoyed a wonderful lunch, shared conversations, and built stronger connections with one another. The event reflected the mission of Atlantic City Senior Services to not only inform, but also uplift and connect the senior community.

It was a meaningful afternoon filled with practical guidance and personal warmth—proof that learning is lifelong, and so is the value of friendship and community support.

item.title: Atlantic City Seniors Enjoyed a Cake Decorating Experience
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: Atlantic City seniors enjoyed a creative afternoon of cake decorating, bringing smiles, frosting, and fun to the community. The event was part of ongoing senior services activities offered by the City.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City – Government recently hosted a fun and flavorful event for local seniors: a cake decorating activity designed to bring joy, creativity, and community engagement to residents aged 55 and older.

Participants tapped into their artistic sides while enjoying hands-on guidance in designing and decorating their own sweet creations. The event was filled with laughter, conversation, and a shared appreciation for the simple joy of trying something new.

The initiative was part of the city’s ongoing commitment to Atlantic City Senior Services, which provides meaningful, engaging, and accessible activities for the community’s older adults. From social events to wellness programs, these efforts aim to keep seniors connected and active.

This cake decorating day was more than just a tasty outing—it was a chance for seniors to gather, create, and celebrate the value of community and lifelong learning.

Additional senior services programs were planned throughout the month, offering residents continued opportunities to enjoy enriching and interactive experiences.

item.title: Bringing Health to the Heart of the Community: Baltic Plaza Health Fair Recap
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: The Community Health Fair at Baltic Plaza brought residents and healthcare providers together for a day of support and wellness. Thanks to community partnerships, essential health resources were made accessible to the people of Atlantic City.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services hosted a successful Community Health Fair at Baltic Plaza, where residents gathered for a day dedicated to wellness, connection, and empowerment. The event aimed to bring vital health resources directly to the community in an accessible and supportive setting.

A wide range of services and information were provided thanks to the collaboration with AtlantiCare, Southern Jersey Family Medical Centers, Inc., and the Cape Atlantic Coalition for Health. These partners played a key role in delivering on-site screenings, health education, and personalized guidance to attendees of all ages.

Residents had the opportunity to speak directly with healthcare professionals, learn about preventative care, and receive materials on maintaining long-term wellness. The fair fostered a welcoming atmosphere where people felt seen, heard, and cared for—underscoring the importance of community-driven public health efforts.

The event also created space for conversations around health equity and access, aligning with the City’s mission to make wellness resources more inclusive and available to all Atlantic City residents.

By the end of the day, new relationships were formed, knowledge was shared, and a stronger sense of community health was established. It was a powerful reminder that public health is most impactful when it meets people where they are.

item.title: Public Safety Academy at Atlantic City High School Announced 2025 Expansion
item.dc:creator: Tasha Devonish
item.description: The Public Safety Academy at Atlantic City High School was set to expand in 2025, offering more career pathways in fire, police, and emergency services. Launched in 2019 and temporarily paused during the pandemic, the program prepared students for real-world roles in public safety.
item.content:encoded:
The Public Safety Academy at Atlantic City High School was announced to expand in 2025, creating even more career-focused opportunities for students interested in public service fields. This initiative continued the school's commitment to preparing students for real-world careers through hands-on learning and mentorship.

Originally launched in 2019, the academy had been temporarily paused due to the challenges brought by the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the interruption, the program remained a vital part of the school’s vision for student success and community involvement.

The academy gave students direct access to experienced professionals from the Atlantic City Fire Department, Police Department, Beach Patrol, and Emergency Medical Services. These partnerships allowed students to gain valuable insight into the demands and rewards of careers in public safety.

The upcoming expansion was expected to broaden the curriculum and bring in additional resources, ensuring that students receive the most relevant training and exposure to various emergency response fields. With the relaunch, more students would have the chance to explore career pathways in service roles that directly impact their communities.

This announcement reaffirmed Atlantic City High School’s role in shaping future leaders and responders through education, access, and opportunity.

item.title: Atlantic City High School Environmental Club Collaborated with Public Works for Campus Cleanup
item.dc:creator: Christina Noble
item.description: The Atlantic City High School Environmental Club joined forces with the Public Works Department for a successful cleanup outside the school. This effort marked a strong start to the city’s upcoming Clean Communities initiative.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City Government recently expressed gratitude to the Atlantic City High School Environmental Club for their collaboration with the Public Works Department during a successful cleanup effort outside the school. The event demonstrated the power of community partnerships and youth involvement in environmental stewardship.

This cleanup was part of the city's ongoing commitment to keeping neighborhoods clean and green. Students from the Environmental Club worked alongside city staff to clear debris and beautify the area around their campus. Their dedication and teamwork were a testament to the positive impact young residents can make when given the opportunity to lead.

The initiative served as a preview of the city’s upcoming Clean Communities campaign, an annual program aimed at encouraging civic pride and environmental responsibility through organized cleanup events.

The City is excited to continue these efforts in the months ahead, building on the success of this recent collaboration and engaging even more community groups and volunteers.

By working together, Atlantic City continues to foster a cleaner, more sustainable future for all residents.

item.title: Inaugural Daddy Daughter Sneaker Ball Brings Families Together in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The City of Atlantic City held its first Daddy Daughter Sneaker Ball, where proud dads and beaming daughters shared a night full of joy, dancing, and unforgettable memories. Organized by AC Rec and city partners, the evening was truly magical.
item.content:encoded:
A new tradition focused on family, connection, and community pride.

When Mayor Marty Small Sr. took office in 2019, he made a promise to create more opportunities for families to come together, celebrate one another, and feel connected to the city they call home. That promise was on full display at Atlantic City’s All Wars Memorial Building during the inaugural Daddy Daughter Sneaker Ball, an event that many hope will become a new Atlantic City tradition.

Organized by the Atlantic City Recreation Division, the Sneaker Ball was a refreshing twist on the traditional father-daughter dance—offering an experience that prioritized fun, fashion, and family. The free event welcomed fathers and father figures from across Atlantic City to attend with their daughters, walking the red carpet, posing for photos, and dancing the night away in outfits that mixed formal flair with comfortable sneakers.

Inside the beautifully decorated venue—thanks to the Mayor’s Office of Special Events—guests enjoyed dinner, desserts, “mocktails,” and giveaways donated by generous local businesses and community partners. These touches reinforced the heart of the event: community support and connection.

While the Recreation Division is known for its sports leagues and youth programs, events like this reflect its broader mission to create meaningful moments that bring people together. Recreation Director Mike Griffin shared that more events like this are already being planned, in addition to the division’s ongoing after-school programming and seasonal trips designed to keep Atlantic City youth active, inspired, and engaged.

Since the Mayor’s first term, Atlantic City has continued to invest in programming that brings joy, promotes unity, and helps families create memories close to home. These types of initiatives speak to a broader goal—making Atlantic City a place where people can thrive, raise their families, find opportunity, and take pride in where they live.

The success of the first-ever Daddy Daughter Sneaker Ball proves that Atlantic City residents are ready to celebrate one another in new ways—and that the city is just getting started. These moments of joy and connection are what make Atlantic City a great place to live, work, and invest.

item.title: Atlantic City Senior Services Enjoys a Day of Bargain Hunting and Tradition
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Trigg
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services took seniors on a joyful trip that combined a first-time visit to the Red White and Blue Thrift Market with a return to the familiar Berlin Market. The day was filled with fun, friendship, and great deals.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Senior Services embraced both the excitement of something new and the comfort of the familiar during a special shopping outing. Participants made their first visit to the Red White and Blue Thrift Market, exploring a new destination filled with unique finds and unbeatable prices.

In addition to this new adventure, the group also returned to a beloved favorite—the Berlin Market—a place filled with memories and familiar vendors. This blend of new and old provided the seniors with an enriching experience full of connection, nostalgia, and discovery.

The day was filled with laughter, shared stories, and plenty of great deals, as everyone enjoyed browsing through treasures and scoring bargains. Whether it was a vintage gem or a fresh find, the excitement of the hunt brought joy to all who joined.

This outing reflected the mission of Atlantic City Senior Services to keep seniors engaged, active, and socially connected through meaningful experiences.

item.title: The Laff House Opens with Laughter and Celebration at ACX1 Studios Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The Laff House at ACX1 Studios launched with a successful opening night, celebrated by Mayor Small and city officials during a ribbon cutting. The venue adds new energy to Atlantic City's comedy and entertainment scene.
item.content:encoded:
The Laff House at ACX1 Studios officially opened its doors in Atlantic City, marking its debut with a lively and laughter-filled opening night. This exciting new venue brought comedy to the forefront of the city’s entertainment scene, offering a fresh space for performers and audiences to connect through humor.

The grand opening event was highlighted by a ribbon cutting ceremony, where Mayor Marty Small and representatives from the City of Atlantic City - Government were in attendance to show their support and celebrate the new addition to the city’s cultural landscape.

As a welcome addition to ACX1 Studios and the broader Atlantic City arts community, The Laff House is expected to draw comedy lovers from across the region. The venue adds a dynamic new layer to the city’s entertainment offerings and creates more opportunities for creative expression.

With a strong start and warm community reception, The Laff House promises to become a beloved space for both local and visiting comedians to share their talent.
